iati-activity.title: PIMS 3929 SCCF FSP
iati-activity.description: PIMS 3929 SCCF FSP Integrating Climate Change Risks into Water and Flood Management by Vulnerable Mountainous Communities in the Greater Caucasus Region.

document-link.title: Integrating Climate change Risks into Water and Flood Management by Vulnerable Mountainous Communities in the Greater Caucasus

iati-activity.title: PIMS 3929 SCCF FSP
iati-activity.description: Project aims to reduce vulnerability of the mountain communities of the Greater Caucasus region of Azerbaijan to climate change induced water stress and flood hazards by improved water and flood management.

transaction.disbursement-channel: Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account

result.title: Objective
result.description: To reduce the vulnerability of the communities of the Greater Caucasus (GC) region of Azerbaijan to water stress and hazards by improved water and flood management.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: # of hectares in the GC affected by improved CRM practices.

baseline.comment: Zero. There are no programs in place currently focused on improving climate risk management in the areas of flood and water management.

target.comment: Improved climate risk management affecting over 22,067 sq. km (2,206,700 ha) of land in highly vulnerable region of Greater Caucasus.

actual.comment:
After replacing of CTA in 2014methodology was revised and updated work plan was prepared. In accordance with the workplan, the project team conducted twelve successful training sessions (see page 6.) on modeling and other related topics. Now to reduce the vulnerability of the Greater Caucasus (GC) region of Azerbaijan, 3 local modelers have been trained in the use of the SOBEK model (hydraulic model) to forecast flood events and based on the result of the model, conducts risk analysis. All collected data was collated and placed on the central computer server installed in the project office. Currently all experts have access to the database are able to use this in the preparation of their deliverables. GIS expert in cooperation with national geologist, national hydrogeologist, national modeler, national hydrologist and lead institutional capacity expert prepared drafts of several types of maps which are evaluate and assesses risks. Also project team prepared Project Atlas where they briefly show the main activities and progress. During the reporting period, the FFEWS specialist developed a new design and Terms of Reference for a full FFEWS in the Pilot Catchments. As a part of the full system, the project has developed Design of community-based FFEWS in consultation with local communities (as a pilot area in Turyanchay RB).
Once funding is available and the system is installed, a total of approximately 300,000 hectares will benefit in the Turyanchay basin.
With minor corrections proposed by the local stakeholders, the concept was agreed with communities and report describing the proposed FFS, implementation and operation of the FFS was developed. Currently, the project is working on the adaptation of this concept to the whole region.
The Project has also identified and prepared a report on Requirements for Flood Forecasting Model(s) for Project Basins. Modelling Scope for a fully Integrated FFEWS. The Project also prepared a detailed specification of equipment required for community-based schemes for the 3 pilot basins. The HEC-HMS hydrologic model was selected as being the most appropriate to use in current study. Project has already conducted trainings on HEC-HMS provided by lead hydrologist/hydraulic structure engineer and set up the HEC-HMS model for the Turyanchay River catchment. During reporting period Water Resources Engineer/IWRM Expert and National Lead Institutional Capacity Development Expert/Gender/Stakeholder /Engagement/Participatory Specialist developed Draft institutional Integrated Water Resources Management (IWRM) framework and submitted it to the government officials (Ministry of Emergency Situations). The same time IWRM expert held three training sessions on IWRM, Conceptual modelling (IWRM, CWM), IWRM practice, Climate change aspects and Conjunctive water management.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: # of people who benefit from locally tailored CRM practices for flood and water risk management.

baseline.comment: Zero. There are no locally tailored climate change adaptation practices in place.

target.comment: 1,000,0000 people benefit from improved CRM practices across the GC region.

actual.comment:
Conducted studies revealed the most vulnerable communities in terms of susceptibility to water/flood risks: Balakan district: Mazim village, Khanifa village, Katekhchay village, Poshtbina village; Zagatala district: Zaqatala city, Ashgi Tala, Goyam village, Suvagil village, Mazikh village, Ititala village, Ashagi Chardakhli village, Uzungazmalar village, Mughanli village; Gakh district: Gakh city, Gashgachay village, Gum village, Almali village, Zayam village, Alibayli village; Sheki district: Sheki city, Shirinbulag village, Okhut village, Bash Goynuk village, Ashagi Goynuk village, Ashagi Shabalid (Selbasan) village, Kish village; Oghuz district: Filfilli village, Khachmaz village, Bash Dashagil village, Mukhas village, Bujag village; Gabala district: Gabala city, Bum settlement, Khirkhatala village, Uludash village, Mikhligovag village, Tikanli village, Hamzali village, Jighatelli village, Vandam village, Abrikh village,Gamarvan village.
Once the flood forecasting and community-based early warning system is implemented, a total of approximately 211,000 persons will benefit.
After a well-attended Workshop on Flood Forecasting and Early Warning Systems for Local Stakeholders on 16 July, 2014 the project team decide to hold meetings with communities in smaller groups (community based) to discuss and identify the specific needs of each group. Project team held a total of 35 meetings with communities in the field and have already started to formulate CRM measure adapted to local conditions and tailored for specific communities throughout the project area. Currently the project is preparing a second workshop with the communities on 5 August, to evaluate all results on FFEWS and to have discussions with the communities on CWM plans. Project is planning to engage around 100 participants.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number and Type of adaptation actions implemented in national development frameworks; (AMAT Outcome Indicator 1.1.1.)

baseline.comment: 0 Normative Legal Acts (NLA); water code does not have IWRM relevant normative legal acts 0 NLA; water code does not have relevant normative legal acts 0 NLA; water code does not have relevant normative legal acts 0 NLA; water code does not have relevant normative legal acts

target.comment: 1 NLA; IWRM principles integrated in water policy 1 NLA; Flood zoning regulations introduced in water code 1 NLA; Conjunctive water management part of the water policy 1 NLA; Public participation and gender representation rules as part of the water and flood management policy

actual.comment: Legal Working Group (LWG) was established on 25 April 2014 and from this date several meetings were held to discuss current legislation and possible changes In NLA. Legal expert has prepared 12 draft proposals and 5 recommendations to: Water Code, Law on Environmental Protection, Law On Amelioration and Irrigation, Law on Ecology Safety, Law on Water Supply and Wastewater, Law on Water Management in Municipalities. All proposal was submitted to Legal Working group and this is now under discussion. During reporting period project team held 3 meetings of the LWG to conduct discussions on proposed changes to NLA. Project also hired an international legal expert to bring international best practices to national legislation. Report on International Legislative and Policy Best Practice in Integrated Water Resources Management as Applicable to Azerbaijan was developed and based on this report, currently national and international legal experts are working on development of the new strategy to integrate and adopt IWRM and CWM principles to the NLAs. (List of the LWG members is attached)

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Water and Flood management framework is modified to respond to adaptation needs and improve climate risk management.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: # of articles included into the Water Code supporting non-structural climate change adaptation practices and their implementation.

baseline.comment: Zero. The Water Code is not sensitized to climate risks in water and flood management.

target.comment: At least 3 new CC-A focused articles included into the water code by end of project.

actual.comment: Draft proposals to Water Code which must support non-structural climate change adaptation practices and integrated water resource management have been prepared and submitted to the Legal Working Group. To study of the international practices on water resources management in 2014, the project hired international legal/policy expert. By the results of the work international legal/policy expert prepared report on International Legislative and Policy Best Practice in Integrated Water Resources Management as Applicable to Azerbaijan. The report is divided into five main sections: Methodology; Water Governance in Azerbaijan; Integrating IWRM into Law; IWRM Legislative and Policy Best Practices; and Recommendations for Azerbaijan. It is then followed by Annexes providing examples of provisions from the national legislation of select countries that reference the various best practices. In order to prepare the final text of the proposal to current NLAs at the end of August 2015 it is planned to re-hire international legal/policy

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Development frameworks include specific budgets for adaptation actions

baseline.comment: no flood zoning policies and regulations (level of action: national, local and community) no conjunctive water management practice (level of action: national, local and community)

target.comment: flood zoning regulations included in flood and river management (level of action: local and ocmmunity level covering 400km of the target river body) conjunctive water management model developed (national, local and community level)

actual.comment:
The Lead Water Resources Specialist has developed the WEAP (Water Evaluation and Planning) model using previously collected data. This has been produced for the Turyanchay basin and is now producing preliminary results on water availability and the introduction of conjunctive water management through the incorporation of the groundwater component.
Engagement with IPs has been difficult from the outset of the project. Reasons for this can be attributed, in part, to the change of Ministry from Ecology to Emergency Situations. This has provoked confusion over responsibilities and obligations. Only now, with concrete proposals for installation of Hydromet equipment on the table, has a significant degree of engagement with SAWR manifested. Without a deeper level of commitment and engagement by this Agency the project will experience difficulty in securing the inclusion of adaptation measures into development frameworks. This activity requires action and engagement from both project and Agency and depends, to a large extent, on timing of the establishment of development frameworks, given that the precise role of the Agency is still under discussion. It is hoped that the projectâ€™s proposals for institutional development of SAWR will accelerate this discussion.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Water Code does/does not mandate unified management or collaborative approaches to reduce climate-induced risk of increased flood damage and water stress.

baseline.comment: Water Code is not sensitized to the importance of collaborative approaches to climate risk reduction.

target.comment: Amended water code mandates unified management and/or collaborative approaches to reducing CC risk of increased flooding and water stress.

actual.comment: Project lead legal/policy specialist presented draft proposals (12 proposals and 5 recommendations to the Water Code to the LWG. Next discussions will held on late August early September with participation of the international legal/policy expert to finalize proposals

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Key institutions have capacities, technical skills, tools and methods to apply advanced climate risk management practices for water stress and flood mitigation.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Capacity Perception Index Score (1 - 5) to be disaggregated by gender 1. No capacity built 2. Initial Awareness raised (e.g. workshops, seminars) 3. Substantial training in practical application (e.g. vocational training) 4. Knowledge effectively transferred (e.g. passing examination, certification) 5. Ability to apply or disseminate knowledge demonstrated. (AMAT Outcome Indicator 2.2.2) Capacity Perception Index Score (1 - 5) to be disaggregated by gender 1. No capacity built 2. Initial Awareness raised (e.g. workshops, seminars) 3. Substantial training in practical application (e.g. vocational training) 4. Knowledge effectively transferred (e.g. passing examination, certification) 5. Ability to apply or disseminate knowledge demonstrated. (AMAT Outcome Indicator 2.2.2)

baseline.comment: Baseline Score for Male and Female = 1. No capacity built for climate change adaptation and risk reduction.

target.comment: Target Score for Male and Female = 3. Substantial training in practical application (e.g. vocational training).

actual.comment:
To study the capacity of the organizations involved to the water resource management National Lead Institutional Capacity Development Expert/Gender/Stakeholder /Engagement/Participatory Specialist based on S.W.O.T. analysis (Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities and Threats) conduct survey. Based on the results of those survey and meetings between project experts and officials of the involved organizations Lead Water Resources Engineer/IWRM Expert with National Lead Institutional Capacity Development Expert/Gender/Stakeholder /Engagement/Participatory Specialist develop ?Draft institutional framework for the implementation of IWRM in Azerbaijan. The Specialists are examining the present and possible future functions of each institution to determine the most appropriate capacity building programmes and elements to define. In order to build technical skills and capacity of the beneficiary and partner agencies project team conduct number of technical training sessions.
Total number of persons receiving training was 125. Institutions and organizations benefitting were:
SAWR, NHD, MoES, Amelioration JSC, AzerSu JSC with the majority of the participants from SAWR. This training included 2 seminars that should be considered under the theme of awareness building rather than the direct technical training given in the following:
1D -2D modeling
Hydata hydrologic database
Conjunctive Water Management
IWRM
HEC Geo RAS
SOBEK 2D modeling
Planning Community Based Early Warning Systems

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: AMAT Output Indicator 2.1.1.1: Updated risk and vulnerability assessment. Yes/No

baseline.comment: No, there is no updated risk and vulnerability assessment

target.comment: Yes. There will be an updated risk and vulnerability assessment by end of project.

actual.comment: National and international experts depending on their tasks assigned to them by ToRs starting to assess vulnerability of the communities and areas in their reports from October 2013. Comprehensive study will be conducted as summary of all experts contributions in mid-2016

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: AMAT Output Indicator 2.1.1.2: Updated risk and vulnerability assessment conducted. Yes/No

baseline.comment: No, there is no updated risk and vulnerability assessment conducted.

target.comment: Yes. An updated risk and vulnerability conducted by end of project as part of project's work to produce model flood risk maps and participatory mapping processes

actual.comment: National and international experts depending on their tasks assigned to them by ToRs starting to assess vulnerability of the communities and areas in their reports from October 2013. Comprehensive study will be conducted as summary of all experts contributions in mid-2016.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: AMAT Output Indicator 2.1.2.1: Number and Type of monitoring systems in place.

baseline.comment: 0 High elevation meteorological stations; 0 River Monitoring meteorological stations; 0 Community-based early warning for floods; 0 Community-based water stress early warning

target.comment: 6 High elevation meteorological stations; 3 High-altitude river monitoring meteorological stations; 3 Community -based early warning for floods; 3 Community-based water stress early warning

actual.comment: Lead hydrometry expert prepared detailed report of existing hydrometry network and proposals of the best available monitoring technology. Expert prepared technical specification for the proof concept gauging station and project based on that announced tender to purchase first pilot gauging station. Three company was attend the tender and by results of the evaluation EPTISA was declared as winner company. Expected delivery of the equipment to Azerbaijan late August, expected installation of Hydromet stations is early September 2015. Meteorological station will be installed in the upper mountain area of the Hamzali village (4103'52,56 N 47050'33,06 E ), hydrological station will be installed in the Savalan district (400 42.766' N 47032.905' E). Preliminary places for the installation of the rest stations was also identify by project consultants. Project consultants Lead Socio-economic expert, National Lead Institutional Capacity Development Expert/Gender/Stakeholder /Engagement/Participatory Specialist and International FFEWS expert conduct consultations with government officials and community representatives. Based on that concept and design of the FFEWS and CBFFEWS was prepared by project expert Juan Fernandez.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Community resilience to floods and water stress improved by introducing locally tailored climate risk management practices.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of WUA created / and or strengthened for CRM with respect to water stress and floods in project area. Percentage increase in representation of women in pilot WUAs.

baseline.comment: Zero Water User Associations (WUA) strengthened for CRM in project area. Women are underrepresented in WUAs.

target.comment: At least 5 by end of year 2; 10 by end of year 4; and 15 by end of project. At least 20% women in all pilot WUAs by end of project

actual.comment: At the recommendation of the project Mid-Term review, the focus of the project activities was adjusted. There was a pressing need for the adoption of adaptive management?, since a number of factors assumed in the original project document were either invalid or, based on findings, somewhat impractical. The strengthening of the WUAs was particularly noted. Awareness among existing WUAs is low and introducing high technology tools (such as SWAT) at this early stage was considered premature and unlikely to be practical. The concentration for WUA strengthening will be an awareness building. It will take some time to convert the existing WUAs (irrigation focused) to full water management activities and the awareness building will lead to this objective.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of Local Stakeholder Committees with at least 20% women representation.

baseline.comment: Zero. There are no such LSCs in place.

target.comment: By end of Year 2, at least 3 Local Multi-Stakeholder Committees (LSCs) actively involved with regional administration in addressing climate change responses and water stress and flood damage mitigation. 6 by end of year 4 and 9 by end of project, all with at least 20% women membership.

actual.comment:
Again, awareness building is an important component of this. Local Stakeholder Committee for Turyanchay is consulted for FFEWS and will be strengthened for IWRM awareness. For today project established 5 WUAs in Turyanchay RB and now work on strengthening of the knowledge and capacity through meeting and trainings for them. Currently project start to establish WUA in Kishchay RB and first meetings was conducted on 21-23 May with three communities. To build strong relations between beneficiary and communities project involved to the meetings MoES and Regional Center specialist.
The project has prepared a list of potential risk reduction and contingency measures that could be implemented locally. These will be discussed with local stakeholder groups and appropriate measures to be implemented will be agreed. (Not all measures will be appropriate to all communities or hazards). Delivery mechanisms anticipated will be via a combination of NGOs, local government agencies and the communities themselves.As a result of gender empowerment at least 30-50% of the WUAs is women

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Relevant risk information disseminated to stakeholders. (AMAT Outcome Indicator 2.1.1).

baseline.comment: No, relevant risk information is not disseminated to stakeholders.

target.comment: Yes, relevant risk information will be disseminated to stakeholders.

actual.comment:
Project was established Working Committee on February 2014 and started discussion on possible and best solution to reach Project targets with stakeholders. This Committee will work until the end of the Project.
Mechanisms for dissemination have been initiated with local workshops, including both community and local agency participation. A subsequent process directed at specific communities is envisaged that will focus the information specifically.
Information brochures have been prepared that summarise both the project in general and the proposed Community-based Early Warning System in detail. These have been distributed extensively.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of rayon's to which climate-risk watershed management planning is replicated.

baseline.comment: Climate-risk watershed management planning has not yet been piloted, much less replicated.

target.comment: 6 climate-risk watershed management plans in addition to the 3 pilot rayons for a total of 9.

actual.comment: Progress expected towards the end of the project. After the project will finalize following researches (as evaluate available climate change information or conduct climate change assessment for areas of interest; analyze climate change impacts; study existing watershed management plans and existing setup in areas of interest; understand water related climate risks and vulnerabilities in areas of interest; participatory development of climate risk mitigation options) it would be possible to develop climate-risk watershed management planning.

result.title: Objective
result.description: Sustainable land and forest management in the Greater Caucasus Landscape secures the flow of multiple ecosystem services, including carbon storage and sequestration, while ensuring ecosystem resilience to climate change.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: # of hectares of forest and pasture lands with improved management.

baseline.comment: Zero

target.comment:
483,800 ha forest
591,100 ha pasturelands in Greater Caucasus over long-term

actual.comment: 17,962 ha of forest and 3,000 ha of pastures under improved management

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: # of hectares and % of pastures (summer and winter) and forestlands in two pilot rayons under improved SLM and SFM.

baseline.comment: Zero

target.comment:
20,000 ha forest under SFM
12,500 ha pastures under SLM

actual.comment:
770 ha of forest
3,000 ha of pastures

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Enabling policy and institutional environment for integrating SLM and SFM principles within the State programs and rayon level land use and forest management frameworks

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: % Improvement in capacity development indicators as per UNDP Capacity Development Scorecard

baseline.comment:
Systemic 43%
Institutional 40%
Individual 42%
Overall 42%

target.comment:
Systemic 63%
Institutional 60%
Individual 62%
Overall 62%

actual.comment:
Systemic 51%
Institutional 51%
Individual 48%
Overall 50%

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Enhanced social capital defined as trust, norms of reciprocity and networks. # of new mechanisms in place

baseline.comment: Zero stakeholder collaboration mechanisms or SLM/SFM-related websites in place

target.comment: 3 new mechanisms in place Rayon stakeholder committees (RSC), pasture user associations (PUA) and Forest users associations (FUA). 1 new open access website/platform for engagement.

actual.comment:
2 Rayon stakeholder committees (RSC) established (1 in each target rayon â€“ Shamakhi and Ismayilli)
2 PUAs and 2 FUAs established in each target region
Website platform is under preparation

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Demonstrated forest recovery and reduction of degradation from grazing and browsing pressures by livestock.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of hectares of pasturelands for which vegetative cover is increased or maintained under improved land use management.

target.comment: 12,500 ha of pastures have maintained or increased vegetative cover as a result of improved land use management.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Avoided emissions from improved pasture management of 12,500 ha.

baseline.comment: 71.1 tC/ha

target.comment: 75.1 tC/ha or 183,337.5 tCO2e over five years.

actual.comment: Not yet calculated; will be available by midterm

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of ha of forestlands under improved multifunctional forest management.

target.comment: 20,000 ha of forestlands under improved multifunctional forest management.

actual.comment: Not yet calculated; will be available by midterm

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Avoided emissions from forest degradation

baseline.comment: 99 tC/ha

target.comment: 102.5 tC/ha or 256,666 t CO2 over 5 years avoided emissions as a result of improved forest management practices.

actual.comment: Not yet calculated; will be available by midterm

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Objectives and methods to enhance carbon storage potential of forests and pastures integrated in forestry and pasture land-use planning and decision-making.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Number of additional tons of CO2e stored in pasturelands and in forests as a result of SLM and SFM practices.

baseline.comment:
71.1 t C/ha pasture
99 t C/ha forest

target.comment:
Improved SLM and SFM practices and restoration on 14,000 ha contribute to carbon storage of
- 311,022 t CO2 eq (9,000 ha in pastureland an increase of 9.425 t C/ha)
- 253,100 tCO2eq (in 5000 ha) in forests associated with 13.8 t C/ha increase.

actual.comment: Not yet calculated

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Increase in forest cover measued by change in mean value of Bonitet classes of forest (lower bonitet class = more productive forest).

baseline.comment:
Rayon/Tree species | Bonitet Class Averages
Ismayilli
Beech | 3.2
Oak | 3.9
Hornbeam | 3.6
Shamakhi
Beech | 3.0
Oak | 4.2
Hornbeam | 3.7

actual.comment:
According to the assessment of the project's experts, the following results were reported:
For Ismayilli rayon:
Beech/Fagus 3.19
Oak/Quercus 3.89
Hornbeam/Carpinus 3.89
For Shamakhi rayon:
Beech/Fagus 2.99
Oak/Quercus 4.19
Hornbeam/Carpinus3.68

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
Area of activity (ha) resulting from project:
Conservation and enhancement of carbon in non-forest lands, including peat land
Avoided deforestation and forest Degradation
Aforestation/reforestation

actual.comment:
Conservation and enhancement of carbon: 0 ha
Avoided deforestation and forest Degradation: 5,000 ha
Aforestation/reforestation: 200 ha MENR; 80 ha under SLFM

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
Lifetime direct GHG emission avoided (tonnes CO2e)
Lifetime indirect GHG emission avoided (tonnes CO2e)
Lifetime direct carbon sequestration(tonnes CO2e)
Lifetime indirect carbon sequestration(tonnes CO2e)

actual.comment:
Pasturelands 183,337.5 tonnes CO2e
Forests 253,100 tonnes CO2e

result.title: Objective
result.description: To improve the management effectiveness, including operational effectiveness and ecosystem representation, of Azerbaijanâ€™s coastal and marine protected area system, with due consideration for its overall sustainability, including ecological, institutional and financial sustainability

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Financial sustainability scorecard for national system of protected areas

actual.comment:
15%
Though the Project Document has been signed by the Government in June 30 2014, its implementation has been delayed to the late appointment of the Project Director and then the creation of the Project Team. During the first year of implementation main activities were concentrated on the purchase of the very basic required equipment, like portable water meter, cars and electronic equipment for the team. Therefore, the financial sustainability of the project remains at the baseline level. Positive changes are expected and they will be reported by the midterm evaluation.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Capacity development indicator score for protected area system

baseline.comment:
Systemic: 34%
Institutional: 20% Individual: 13%

target.comment:
Systemic: 50%
Institutional: 40%
Individual: 25%

actual.comment:
Systemic: 34%
Institutional: 20%
Individual: 13%
Same as above, the main focus in the first year of implementation was to get the project running through addressing basic equipment needs, like portable water meter, cars and electronic equipment for the team. The capacity development indicator will be measured and reported by the midterm review.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Total annual budget (HR, OPEX and CAPEX) allocation for marine and coastal PAs (US$/ha)

baseline.comment:
All PAs: US$3.03/ha
Gizil-Agaj: US$ 2.53/ha

target.comment:
All PAs: US$4/ha
Gizil-Agaj: US$4/ha

actual.comment:
All PAs: US$3.11/ha
Gizil-Agaj: US$ 1.97/ha
At first sight, it looks like the total annual allocations for Marine and Coastal Protected areas has increased overall, but decreased for Gizil-Agaj. In reality, however, in AzN terms (local currency of Azerbaijan), the funding for all marine and costal areas, including Gizil-Agaj area has increased. In February 2015, AzN depreciated by 34% against the dollar . Therefore, if calculated using the exchange rate before AzN depreciation, respective numbers for all marine protected areas would be $4.16/ha ($3.11x1.34=$4.16) and for Gizil-agaj - $2.64/ha ($1.97x1.34=$2.64)

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool scorecard: Gizil-Agaj

actual.comment:
25%
For the reasons already stated above, management effectiveness of the Gizil-Agaj PA remains at the baseline level. Positive changes are expected and they will be reported by the midterm evaluation.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Enhanced management effectiveness of the Gizil-Agaj reserve complex

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Extent (ha) of area surveyed, and formally proclaimed and managed as the Gizil-Agaj national park

baseline.comment: 0 ha

actual.comment:
0 ha
The Gizil-Aga area still has a status of the protected area. Its proclamation as the national park is expected by the end of the Project when required justifications and legal statutes are prepared and approved, which is in the project's plan for the following years.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Total number of mixed breeding population of Pelecaniformes and Ciconiiformes in Gizil-Agaj

actual.comment:
70000
No survey and estimations of the number of species in the protected area were conducted in the reporting period. Such surveys are scheduled by the project for the end of this year and results will be reported in the next PIR.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Total number of wintering waterbirds in Gizil-Agaj

actual.comment:
400,000 - 500,000
No survey and estimations of the number of species in the protected area were conducted in the reporting period. Such surveys are scheduled by the project for the end of this year and results will be reported in the next PIR.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Average number (#/month during spawning season) of illegal sturgeon poaching incidents (or violation of fishing permits) occurring in Gizil-Agaj

baseline.comment:
Spring: 8
Autumn: 6

target.comment:
Spring: <2
Autumn: <2

actual.comment: 51 cases of illegal sturgeon poaching were registered by an authorised service of the Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources. The reported data, however, show the total number of illegal incidents for both winter and spring seasons. The Project Team will request the Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources to provide data disaggregated by seasons for the next reporting period.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Average number (#/month during winter) of recorded illegal bird hunting incidents occurring in Gizil-Agaj

baseline.comment: Winter: 25/month

target.comment: Winter: <10/month

actual.comment:
Winter: < 14/month
On average, 14 cases of illegal bird hunting per month during the winter season were registered by the Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources.

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: Average number (#/month/year) of cattle illegally grazing in Gizil-Agaj

baseline.comment: 500/month

target.comment: <10/month

actual.comment: 653 cases of cattle illegal grazing in Gizil-Agaj were registered by the Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources during the entire year, or 54 illegal incidents per month on average. Even though the reported monthly average is still significantly high compared to the EoP target of 10, it is already significantly lower than the baseline indicator.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Improved collaborative governance of, and institutional expertise in, the financial management of marine and coastal protected areas

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Income/annum (US$), by source, from marine and coastal protected areas

baseline.comment:
Government: US480,822
Donors: US$277,720
Entry fees: US3,902$
Tourism services: US$0
Fines: US$45,356
Resource use: US$0
Concessions: US$0
(baseline year = 2011/2012)

target.comment:
Government: US$750,000
Donors: US$500,000
Entry fees: US$15,000
Tourism services: US$10,000
Fines: US$75,000
Resource use: US$10,000
Concessions: US$10,000
(target year = 2016/17)

actual.comment:
According to the Ministry of Ecology and Natural Resources, the reported income by source is as follows:
Government:US$545,523
Donors:US$190,000
Entry fees:US$ 2,611
Tourism services:US$0
Fines:US$40,833
Resource use: US$0
Concessions: US$0
The decrease in the donor funding for the marine protected areas is explained by the fact that donor funding varies between years depending on the particular activities and expenses planned for that particular year. In some years, there is an increase, and in some years, some decrease in donor funding depending on particular steps. This decrease is not an indicator of diminishing attention to the marine protected areas on the side of donors.
In turn, the small decrease in the entry fees is explained mainly by the exchange rate change between USD and the local currency. The decrease is attributed mainly to the exchange rate change. Current $2611, by taking into account 34% local currency devaluation would bring current fees to 3499 AzN, slightly below the baseline amount of $ 3902. Also, not forget that the number of tourists also varies between years, therefore, depending on many trivial reasons, like weather during holiday period, or something else, Still, the MENR pays attention to this issue and the last year made necessary changes in the regulation, allowing now for visitors to buy entrance tickets directly from the National parks. The MENR understands that such a low entrance fee collection is unsatisfactory, and takes measures to increase the entrance fee collection by using propaganda and easing access to the sites.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Number of MENR staff completing in-service financial training and skills development programmes

actual.comment:
0
There were no trainings or other capacity-building activities conducted during the first year of project implementation. The project is on track, and respective capacity-building activities are planned for the second and third years of project implementation.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of non-state stakeholder institutions and private sector businesses investing in, and/or supporting the administration of, marine and coastal protected areas

baseline.comment:
Donor agencies: 2
NGOs: 1
Private businesses: 0

target.comment:
Donor agencies: 4
NGOs: 2
Private sector: 2

actual.comment:
Donor agencies: 2
NGOs: 1
Private businesses: 0
The Project inception workshop was held in Baku with participation of many stakeholders. Also, the project conducted a meeting with the local community in Baligchilar settlement during the reporting period. After the meeting with the local community the idea emerged to conduct the meeting also with the schoolchildren and their teachers at the local school. This meeting was also held successfully, with Q&A session following the information session with the respective prices for the most knowledgeable students. However, no new partners emerged yet during first year of implementation. It is expected that there will be enhanced participation in the coming years of project implementation.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of business plans operational in individual marine and coastal national parks

actual.comment:
0
Development of business plans is scheduled at later stages of project implementation. The reason being that initially the protected area should be provided with currently absent basic equipment, capacity building and grown ownership of the projected area. As initial surveys are shown, reflected in the baseline surveys, no business plans are yet for the marine protected areas in Azerbaijan. There is no respective expertise in Azerbaijan yet. Therefore, the project team is in the process of development of the respective ToR to hire an international expert to assist the MENR and the Project Team in the development of business plan. There is a positive feeling, based on the steps already made, that the planned target will be achieved.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Number of indicators of ecosystem health being regularly monitored and used to guide decision-making in marine and coastal protected areas

actual.comment:
0
The resource base of the Protected area has been significantly improved through the purchase of important equipment, like portable water meter kits. Even though no progress can be reported in this PIR, significant advances are expected in the following years of project implementation.
